dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fresh flowers are delivered to the loading dock of an ups Chinese restaurant. Hands pick up a tub of long-stemmed, white flowers and ferry them through a kitchen where food preparation has begun. Vegetables are chopped. Woks are t down off hooks. Ducks get stuffed, etc. The hands move through swinging kitchen doors and into an elegant dining room. A slender vase sits in the middle of a plain white tablecloth. The hands insert three of the flowers in the vase, removing offending leaves and fluffing up the arrangement. The camera retreats to reveal a dining room of similarly accoutred tables and satisfied restaurant manager HUE LING. HUE returns through the kitchen doors and picks up a tray pre-cut fortune cookie dough. He holds the tray over his as he, again, navigates the kitchen. He sets it down in f of a frazzled twenty-something-year-old non-Asian, GARRET HENRY.

dialogues.speaker: HUE
dialogues.text: No more fortunes with the word "suckle" in them.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HUE
dialogues.text: A customer last night brought me his wife's fortune and it had the word "suckle" in it.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Do you remember how it was used?

dialogues.speaker: HUE
dialogues.text: I don't care how it was used! No more suckle.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: It's another word for nourish, you know.

dialogues.speaker: HUE
dialogues.text: Then use "nourish," just no more suckle, «Suckling, «may one day suckle.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Bisuckle? MR. HUE wags a warning finger at GARRETT who takes a blac felt tip pen and adds the word suckle to a list that incl the words "dictator," "sponge," and "yankee."  Fortune Cookie - 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casually-dressed TRENT KENNEDY enters his living room carrying mail. The home avoids usual bachelor trappings. There are no Ferrari Poster or dishes piled in sink, etc. entire wall is lined with full bookshelves, but miscellan books are strewn about as well. TRENT pushes play on his answering machine. He enters his kitchen and approaches a crib. We can't see who/what he's talking to.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Hey little guy. Still illin'?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hey Trent. This is Teresa. God, this is embarrassing, but I think I left a pair of earrings over there last weekend. Anyway, they sort of go with what I'm wearing tonight, and I was wondering if maybe--if you're not going to be there-- if you could leave them out in your mailbox. I can just run by and pick them up later. ..0r whatever. TRENT walks back into his bedroom and pulls out the drawe his night stand. He opens a cigar box revealing condoms, dozen earrings, and a couple watches.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Shit. TRENT rifles through the box while a second message plays

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: This is Kevin--Kevin from the Black Hearted Irish. I was wondering if you were going to play that single I sent you on your show anytime soon? Give me a call. The third message is again TERESA.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: They're green. And dangly. Relieved, TRENT pulls the correct pair of earrings out of box. He grabs an envelope off his desk and seals the earr inside.  Fortune Cookie - 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeen-year-old HEATH PATTERSON inserts a compact disk into a jambox. The Jackson Five's "I'll Be There" purrs o of the speakers. Arms outstretched, he performs a cornbal waltz towards his sister, twenty-three-year-old BETH PATTERSON. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: They won't really play this, will they?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I want to be prepared for anything. BETH grabs her brother's hands and places them on her hip Then she puts her hands on his shoulders. She leads them a slow dance shuffle.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So this is it? This is simple!

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I'm leading.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: So? I don't have a problem with that. She can lead.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: She might expect you to. Here. I'm going to stop, and you take over. After an awkward moment, the two resume the dance.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: This isn't too hard.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Remember, there is a beat. HEATH works to find the beat.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: You may not realize this, but we kids today--what with the decline in family values and all--dance a bit closer than this.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: We're doing what is commonly known among the female sex as type four dancing. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 4.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Ah, type four. Maybe I should be taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Perhaps. Notice the signs. We could fit a third person between us. My hands rest lightly and significantly above your hip bone. I'm staring not at you, but at the cute basketball player across the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: And type four dancing represents?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Utter disinterest.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Show me type three. BETH moves in closer to her brother.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: OK, type three. Friendlier. Room to chat without bumping noses, but the invisible wall is still there. She's reserving judgement, but you've got her attention.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I'd take type three.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Who is this girl anyway?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: A sublime beauty. A goddess. Poetry in a supermodel's body. Her name's Doug.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: That's poetic.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Ann Douglas, but everyone calls her Doug.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: And I assume she's been making a fool of herself pursuing you.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: It's been embarrassing, really. The two dance for a moment in silence. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 5.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The truth is, I'm not sure she knew my name before I asked her out. She's in my trig class.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Pretty gutsy.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Show me type two. BETH closes in on HEATH, eliminating the gap between them

dialogues.speaker: HEATH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (feigning disgust) Your things--they're touching me. Hey! Hey! Hey! Watch the hands, sister!

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (ignoring him) Here's where you'll want to slide your hands down to the middle of her back. Unless they're sweaty. If they're sweaty, put ‘em on her hips ..on her jeans where she won't notice.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Is this where the sweet nothings come in?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Whoa, Tiger. We don't even have the training wheels off yet. So what made this girl say yes if she didn't know who you were?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Boatloads of charm. Plus, and probably more importantly, she just gut publicly dumped by a jock of some renown

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: And like a circling buzzard, my brother...

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: .Swooped down on the carcass.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: A class act. The pair type-two dances for a few more seconds. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 6.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Okay, this is starting to creep me out. I think I've got it. They separate and plop down in chairs.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Well let's hope she doesn't expect to be dipped.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Let's hope. So what are your plans for this glorious Friday night? You think they might tie up all the loose ends on The X Files.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Uh, I have a date.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Our long national nightmare is over. Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: His name is Trent. He works at that radio station you and all your little skinhead buddies listen to.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: If you insist on labeling us--we're "alternative." Oh wait a minute. I don't believe it. My sister has a date with Trent "The Dead" Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I do?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I think Mom and Dad should know about this.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: He seemed nice.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: How'd you meet him?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: He's in my book club.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: The Ala-Geek-win Round Table. Well, he can read. We can put that in the plus (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3 Fortune Cookie - 7.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HEATH (cont'd) column. You suppose once you marry him I can get free concert tickets?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: It's just dinner.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Maybe a bumper sticker?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: It probably won't amount to anything.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: (baiting his sister) He's no Daniel, hunh?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Lay off, Heath.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry, but as cool as Daniel was, the dude's gone. He made his decision. I say it's time to get over it.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: If I ever see Daniel again, I'll tell him it's over between the two of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of expensive looking cars wait in a circular drive next to a gymnasium. CAROLYN DOUGLAS, sitting behind the steering wheel of the one clunker in the row, reads Fortu Magazine as she waits for her daughter DOUG. A group of p pom carrying girls approach the cars. They tell each othe goodbye or, alternately, "see you tonight." DOUG gets in clunker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still engrossed in the article, CAROLYN absently starts t engine.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: How was practice?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: It was there.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Mmm hmm (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 8.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: We were making one of those giant pyramids today. And you know James, that dwarf we just added to the squad? The one they experiment on in biology lab? Well he was the top of the pyramid.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (absently) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Yeah? Anyway, I was supposed to be spotting, but I realized that I hadn't painted my nails, so I wandered over to my purse to get the polish--I saw no option--and then I heard this thud followed by all these manic cheerleaders screaming.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (still engrossed in magazine) Uh huh...

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I ran back to where I was supposed to be standing, and there was James laying ina pool of blood, staring up, his eyes still open. He looked like that picture in our history book of Robert Kennedy after he had been assassinated. DOUG poses briefly like Robert Kennedy on the floor of th Ambassador Hotel. CAROLYN starts the car, and begins to p out of the lot.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Blockbuster stock is up again.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: They're the fastest growing franchise in America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls carefully out of the lot into light suburba traffic. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 9.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (between resignation and anger) Wow. A moment of silence as the car continues down the street.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: You don't suppose James' family is going to sue us?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Blood from a stone, Mom. Blood from a stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nervous forty-year-old DEAN JEFFRIES stares at engagement rings through a glass case. A humorless and matronly SALE CLERK waddles over.

dialogues.speaker: SALES CLERK
dialogues.text: Is there anything you'd like to take a closer look at sir?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Uh, that one. The SALES CLERK withdraws the ring from the case and hand to DEAN. DEAN examines the dangling price tag. A look of concern passes across his face.

dialogues.speaker: SALES CLERK
dialogues.text: Three months salary is the rule of thumb sir.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SALES CLERK
dialogues.text: For how much you should spend, that is.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Who do you suppose came up with that rule?

dialogues.speaker: SALES CLERK
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Well--and this is only a theory--but I suspect that whoever decided that three month's salary was the rule was sitting on your side of the counter. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 Fortune Cookie - 10.

dialogues.speaker: SALES CLERK
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know. DEAN holds the ring up and admires it. He wants to get it

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I think they were in cahoots with whoever invented Secretaries Day.

dialogues.speaker: SALES CLERK
dialogues.text: No, those were the flower shop people. We had nothing to do with that. DEAN laughs. The SALES CLERK still refuses to smile.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I have a question. The SALES CLERK stares at DEAN who remains uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you return them?

dialogues.speaker: SALES CLERK
dialogues.text: Within seventy two hours.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Um.. Do you.. I mean... Is there...

dialogues.speaker: SALES CLERK
dialogues.text: No questions asked, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Do people laugh? Point and stare?

dialogues.speaker: SALES CLERK
dialogues.text: Not until you've left the premises. DEAN continues to study the ring.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: SALES CLERK
dialogues.text: Will that be cash or credit?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I'll be using my first born.

dialogues.speaker: SALES CLERK
dialogues.text: I'll find a fancy box.  Fortune Cookie - 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera reveals an expansive and pristine Blockbuster Vide outlet, then pans to its neighbor, the nookish "Les Video

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROLYN stands behind the counter while DOUG shelves vide in the tiny store.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: The Unbearable Lightness of Being. It was about Czechoslovakia, but it was made in England.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: True.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Thanks, but where does it go.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: In the Daniel Day Lewis section.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Oh. You realize this is the reason that in the history of civilization no one has ever been able to find a movie at a video store without asking. I think we should start a trend. Let's just alphabetize every last one of them. No more subdividing by category, by country, by star, by director. Every movie in it's place.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Most people don't come in looking for a particular film. Most come in and browse. They like all the comedies being together. They like all the subtitled films together. There's an article in Video Entrepreneur that explains the strategy if you want to read about it.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) The new issue of Video Entrepreneur came in and you didn't tell me?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I was saving it for a special occasion. Your birthday isn't far off. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 12.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Mom, why don't you just sell Blockbuster this space, marry Dean, and live happily ever after.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Don't you dare mention the M word in front of Dean.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You've been going out, what, a year?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: To the day.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Well I want to know what his intentions are. He's a great guy. You're crazy about him. I'm tired of you two having to sneak around behind my back. I don't see what the hold up is here.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Honey, there are things you don't know about Dean.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: He's a vampire, a bloodsucking prince of darkness. I had a feeling he was too good to be true.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: And that's not even that bad part, honey. The thing is.. The thing is..

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: The thing is...

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: The thing is that it's none of your business, but just know that Dean is understandably a little gun-shy when it comes to marriage.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: And how do you feel about it?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I can think of worse things, but I'm not going to let Dean know that. I'm sure it would scare him to death. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 13.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Are you doing something with him tonight?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Yes, and speaking of which, don't you have a dance to start getting ready for?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Don't remind me.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Not looking forward to it?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I think I'm going to call him and tell him I can't go. Help me think of something. Hey, you said you wanted to start staying open late. Let's start tonight. I'll work.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: You don't like this boy you're going with?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I don't know him. I don't know why he asked me. I was just too shocked to think of anything to say except yes. God, everybody in school knows I'm single, and Troy's already asked a freshman--A FRESHMAN--to the dance. Most of the time, if I have a clue somebody likes me who I don't want to go out with, I can manage to avoid being alone with him, or I'll already have an excuse--a good one-- just right there, ready, you know. At the tip of my tongue. This guy tricked me. He gave none of the usual preliminary signs.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: The usual signs?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Stuttering. Shortness of breath. Describing his car stereo.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Is he cute?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: That's the thing: I've never noticed. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 14.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I don't think you can back out on a date to a formal dance four hours beforehand. He's probably already rented a tux.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Probably white. Probably with tails and a top hat. A pink cummerbund.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: You know we used to think of dating as a chance to get to know people.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You and Betty and Wilma?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: You know I met your father on a blind date.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: That settles it. I'm staying home.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I think you should go.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I'll make you a deal.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I'll go, but you've got to promise to snatch that corsage out of his hand right off. Otherwise I'll end up bleeding and felt up before I'm even out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: And you promise not to run up and hug Dean and call him Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You gotta learn to take a joke, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All six primary characters and GARRETT will be interviewe their own environments. During Garrett's interview, restaurant employees continue to clean, vacuum, etc. behi him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 11 12 13 Fortune Cookie - 15.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: The notice in the English grad student lounge said "Creative Writers Needed Bad," and of course, someone had added "Competent Grammarian Needed Worser" below that. When I saw it, I couldn't figure out what a Chinese Restaurant would need a "creative writer" for, but I needed a job. Mr. Hue told me the concept. He wanted someone who would write fortunes. You know..for the fortune cookies. No two, he said, could ever be the same. He didn't want any that said, "Confucious say, yadda yadda." He didn't want them pulled out of quotation books. And they had to be handwritten. He told me to give him one on the spot. I said, "Nine dollars an hour is a small price to pay for piece of mind." So I got the job. I try to be philosophical about it. I figure in the literary hierarchy, what I do comes somewhere between being the lyricist for Bryan Adams and writing street signs. Some of those street signs are brilliant by the way. I saw one once that said, "Men Laying Pipe Beware." I would have signed my name to that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRENT sits in front of his high tech stereo system. He ha several CDs laid out in front of him: Van Morrison, Terre Trent D'arby, Elvis Costello, Bob Marley, etc. He humms " in the mood for love" as he refers to the song listings o the CDs and programs in appropriate mood music. He adjust the volume to a level that's been marked on the amplifier he pushes the final two buttons on the CD player, he spea

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Repeat. Infinity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETH opens her closet. All of her dresses are black. Without much thought she reaches for one of the garments lays it out across the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEATH is fully decked out in his tux. He gazes at the dig clock impatiently waiting for it to change.  14 15 16 Fortune Cookie - 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG talks on the phone. She is still in her gym clothes. is upset.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I can't believe I'm hearing this. Remember, YOU thought we were getting "too serious." YOU thought we ought to see other people. Do the words "we can still be friends" sound familiar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEAN showers. We see only a silhouette, but we can hear t shower radio which is broadcasting an advertisement featu a bickering married couple, both with grating voices.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Didn't I tell you to fix the roof?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I told ya! I'm watching the game!

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: You lazy good-for-nothing..

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Nag. Nag. Nag.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Sound familiar? Maybe it's time you... We see DEAN'S silhouetted head bang into the shower radio effectively turning it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROLYN finishes loading an automatic drip coffee maker, setting it for 5 a.m. When she's finished this, she scrat an item off of a "to-do" list on the counter. She pulls m out of the refrigerator, sniffs it, then dumps it out. Ag she crosses an item off her list. Referring to her list, goes to the bottom of a stairway and yells.

dialogues.speaker: CARYOLYN
dialogues.text: Ann, you need to get off the phone and start getting ready.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (frustrated) In a minute! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 17 18 Fortune Cookie - 17.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CAROLYN crosses this chore off her list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRENT straightens up his house. The books that have been laying about the living room he returns to shelves. Then, thinking a bit about it, he pulls "The Color Purple" and collected poems of Yeats from the shelves. He inserts a bookmark in one and leaves it conspicuously out on the co table. The other he places spread eagle in another unavoidable location.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETH is now outfitted in her modest black dress. She walk into the living room of her apartment where her roommate AMANDA sits watching The Love Boat.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: That Gopher...

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You know the plan?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Page you at eleven p.m.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Should I set an alarm?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: No, but you should take a chill pill.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Let's see. Am I forgetting anything?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (facetiously) You think we should synchronize watches?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. When you go to the store, could you pick me up a pint of Ben & Jerry's?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Traditional cure-all for post date blues.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You got it.  19 20 21 22 23 Fortune Cookie - 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEATH continues to stare at the clock. As it turns 7:45, gets up deliberately, picks up the corsage sitting on his desk, takes one last look at himself in the mirror, and marches out of the house and to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEATH sets the corsage on the passenger seat, puts the ke the ignition and turns it. Nothing happens. He stares blankly. Then he calmly removes the keys, opens the small blade on his Swiss Army Knife and pretends to perform Har Kara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG is still in her gym clothes and on the telephone. Sh upset but has mellowed a bit.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: «I've missed you too. ..Yeah. ..Yeah. I know what you mean. ..Have you told your new little friend? After tonight? You want to get back together AFTER the dance? ..Well which is worse, telling her before the dance or after? God, Troy, you want your cake and you want to eat it too. ..Yeah, but if you ate it, you wouldn't have it any more. Forget it, Troy, it's an expression. Just a second, I've got a calling coming in. DOUG clicks over to the second call.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEATH scrubs grease off his hands. He's got the cordless phone propped up next to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Uh, Doug. This is Heath.I'm sorry I'm running late. I'm have had some minor car problems here, but it's about taken care of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG finally looks at the clock. She had almost succeeded forgetting her own date. She is speechless.  24 25 26 27 Fortune Cookie - 19.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Uh, Doug? Uh, I'm sorry, is Doug there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG stares at a picture of herself with a boy we assume Troy.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: This is Doug. Okay. That's no problem, Heath. In fact, I've been having some problems with my dress, so, uh, take your time. ..Okay. ..See you then. DOUG clicks back over to Troy.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey Troy? Look. I'll just see you at the dance. Maybe you'll get to meet my date. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROLYN rolls on deodorant. She scratches an item off her list. She applies lipstick and once again scratches an it off. She refers to the list.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (reading) Shower. She looks up disgustedly at her reflection and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEAN works on getting his tie right. The TV in his room i tuned into the news.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER
dialogues.text: The latest allegations levied by Prince Charles against Lady Di involve rumors of... DEAN uses the remote control to switch to a sports channe

dialogues.speaker: SPORTSCASTER
dialogues.text: The football team may be leaving Cleveland, but the city is keeping its name. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 28 Fortune Cookie - 20.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DEAN flips channels again.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: We return to Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis in... Flipping once more, DEAN lands on the Discovery channel. Onscreen, two amoeba's split apart. He turns the TV off, exits the room, working on his tie as he departs. He retu to the room a minute after the door closes and retrieves ring he has left on the bureau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG is frantically putting on makeup. CAROLYN is blow dr her hair.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Honey, will your generation of women ever appreciate what mine has done for you.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You heard from Blockbuster again?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: "Mrs. Douglas, we have the utmost respect for you, Les Video and your clientele. You've really taught us a thing or two about persistence."

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What's wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: What do you mean, what's wrong with it? It's patronizing. Persistence is just another way of saying I'm stubborn.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Sounds fine to me. Where's Dean taking you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: That Chinese place, the one with the fortune cookies. Well there's more. They've upped the offer another five percent.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Those bastards. The Empire? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 21. 28

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: The offer part's fine. It's this next line. "We would also accept you into our advanced management training program." Then they say something about where they'd transfer me and how much money I'd make when I got out. The Empire sounds right.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Wow, fancy. How much would they pay you?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: That's not the point. I've been managing a store for ten years. What do I need to go to Blockbuster management school for? Are they going to teach me how to make an eye-catching display using eighty copies of Tango & Cash? Noticing DOUG'S transformation... CAROLYN (cont'd) You certainly are dressed to kill. I thought you weren't interested in this boy.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: It's not for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRENT sits in the DJ booth at an alternative rock station Something grungy buzzes out of the earphones hanging arou his neck.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: There was this time--I think I was 16-- that I got asked to one of those Sadie Hawkins dances by this girl I didn't really know, but I said yes because, you know, I didn't want to be a dick. Technically, the girl is supposed to pick you up, but she didn't have a car and she lived like a thousand miles outside of town, so I drove out to get her. The first thing I do when I get there is lock my keys in the car. As if that's not enough, the motor's running, her parents have left for the evening, and my Dad's not home, so we're just stuck there. At first it's unbelievably awkward, but every time we look at the car we just (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 30 Fortune Cookie - 22.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TRENT (cont'd) bust out laughing. We end up going sledding on a big hill near her house which is a blast. You know how you have to hold on to each other, and we're screaming and laughing. We're out there living some sort of Norman Rockwell painting, and I'm thinking, "Gee, this girl is swell." Our fourth or fifth time down the hill, we slide into this huge pile of slush. When her parents get home, I'm standing in front of the fireplace in nothing but her Dad's bathrobe and a smile. But the Dad is cool. He's like, "Could I get you my slippers, Son?" I think that was the last time I had a good time on a date. Before it became a science. God, I can't even remember if I kissed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRENT arrives at BETH'S door. Dressed sharply, he carries single rose. He knocks. BETH answers. AMANDA remains on t couch facing both the TV and the door.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Hi. You ready?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (concerned) I don't look ready?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: No, I mean yeah, you look ready. It was rhetorical..sort of. I guess I meant are you available to leave?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: A flying start.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Yeah, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (holding out rose) This is for you.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Thanks. BETH holds the flower self-consciously trying to decide whether she should carry it or leave it in a vase. TRENT notices. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 3 Fortune Cookie - 23.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I got it from one of those sidewalk vendors. They say selling flowers keeps them off crack.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: A single rose means I love you. BETH and TRENT, both horrified, turn and gape at AMANDA.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Manners.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Just thought you should know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEATH fidgets in the living room. CAROLYN puts on her own shoes as she tries to stall for her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Ann says the two of you have math together.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Trig--and boy does it come in handy. There's a pause while CAROLYN decides whether HEATH is be intentionally funny.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Ann says those college prep course are difficult.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Pretty tough. A moment of awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: So what are your plans?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Well, after graduation, I think I want to go to a four-year school, you know, study art, maybe go into animation.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Uh, I'll need Ann home before that. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 Fortune Cookie - 24.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Sorry. You mean tonight. Dinner before the dance at Louie's On The Lake. A bunch of friends of mine are eating there. Then I was going to take her to this coffee shop down by the university. They've got one of my pieces on display there. I don't know. You think that would look like showing off?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I'm not sure what... CAROLYN stops speaking when she sees HEATH'S jaw drop. Be her DOUG has entered the room looking stunning. HEATH sta up. He's holding the corsage box in his trembling hand.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you like some help with that, Heath? HEATH hands the box off to CAROLYN without taking his eye off DOUG.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Hi, sorry I'm running late.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: These aren't the socks I wanted to wear.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Oh, what do you know? This is a wrist corsage. CAROLYN helps DOUG on with the corsage while HEATH fidget

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, Ann, I want you home no later than... DOUG mouths the word "early" to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: midnight.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Oh, mom.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Midnight, and I mean it. I need you to inventory the store in the morning. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 25.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CAROLYN works the group towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you, Heath.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Thanks, you too.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I think she'd like to see your work.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: See his what? CAROLYN closes the door on the couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As HEATH and DOUG stroll up the sidewalk, DEAN pulls up i front of the house.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Hey, Dean!

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Kiddo. Bowling tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Tractor pull. Unintroduced, HEATH stands uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Is your mom ready?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: For a hostile takeover, yes. For a date? Who knows.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Actually, with our dates, it's tough to tell the difference.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (covering her ears) I don't want to hear about it. DOUG finally remembers HEATH.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dean, this is Heath. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 33 Fortune Cookie - 26.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Hi. None of the pretty girls willing to go with you? HEATH laughs nervously.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: We have math together.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Trig.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Maybe you'll be able to get some homework done tonight. DEAN reaches out to shake Heath's hand. When he does, the ring box falls out of the jacket he's carrying. He stuffs back in his pocket quickly, but not before DOUG notices.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (upon box retrieval, shaking Heath's hand) Sorry about that. Never know when you're going to need that spare glass eye. Good to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: We better go. Mom gives him demerits for tardiness. See ya, Dean. DOUG leads HEATH away.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (calling after them) Have fun. DEAN knocks on the door while opening it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEAN enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Hi, honey. I'm home. DEAN plops down on the couch and kicks his feet up on an ottoman. CAROLYN enters room with a cordless phone presse her ear. She nods at DEAN, but continues the conversation (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 27. 33

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (angrily) No, you see, I wouldn't be calling you at home if you returned my calls from your shop which is where you should be anyway. You promised me those VCRs last week.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Big day at the office.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I rent them. You fix them. It works better that way.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Naw, you wouldn't want to hear about it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Well where are the parts coming from? The eighteenth century? We have this thing now. It's called next-day delivery?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Okay, Okay. They want me to head up the new software division.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: No they don't use ponies anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: And, from what I understand, San Francisco is a beautiful city.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Can I get that in blood?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Good weather. Fancy rice dishes.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Always a pleasure, Mr. Willis.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Great restaurants. CAROLYN clicks the phone off emphatically.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: What about great restaurants?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: We're going to one. You ready?  Fortune Cookie - 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRENT and BETH drive to the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: It's called The Empire. Have you heard of it?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I've just been a couple times. Food's great. Service is unbelievable. And they have this thing.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: This thing?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: This thing they do. They handwrite your fortunes in the fortune cookies. Last time I went the ink was still wet.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: That's hygienic. Do you remember what it said?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Clearly. It said, "Risk your heart without fear. Loneness gone. Romance near."

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: And was it?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Real near. The guy one table over from me was performing a non-surgical tonsillectomy on his date.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: God, I hate that.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: It said "loneness"--not loneliness?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: That's what made me remember it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 35 Fortune Cookie - 29.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I don't know if I like that. I mean, loneliness is bad--we can all agree on that--but I'm not sure "loneness" is.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: It's like people think that if you're alone, you're automatically unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I'm very content by myself.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Same here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG and HEATH ride in Heath's car in uncomfortable silen

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Hey, what do you think about eating at The Empire?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: (hesitating) Sounds fine.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Did you already have plans?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: No, not really. The pair returns to the uncomfortable silence.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Jeffries coached me in Little League.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Dean? He didn't remember you?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I was seven at the time. I think he might have if I would have sat next to him and yelled, "Hey batter, batter, batter, batter, swwwwwwing" Again with the silence.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't you hate Mrs. Shropshire? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 30.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Yeah. You have her for government?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Civics?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: (uneasily) No.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Have you ever had her for a class?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: So why do you hate her?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I've just heard, you know, people say things that, I guess, umm, make me hate her.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: The food in the cafeteria--that's really bad too.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I've never had any.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Well, I don't recommend it. More uncomfortable silence.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't think the Beatles were all that great either. DOUG looks quizzically at HEATH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROLYN drives DEAN to the restaurant. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 37 Fortune Cookie - 31.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I can't believe you're not even going to mention it.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Mention what?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: You know what. Did anything special happen down at the accounting firm of Ross and Harvey today?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Oh. You mean the stripper who came in and sang happy anniversary to me in the middle of a staff meeting.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: It wasn't a stripper. It was a man ina gorilla suit.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Boy, I sure wasted a lot of dollar bills, then. And, once again, you one-upped me.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: The flowers you sent were lovely. DEAN rests his head on CAROLYN'S shoulder as she drives.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I did not one-up you. CAROLYN wraps her arm around Dean's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Honey, that light was red.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: No it wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The restaurant is operating at full-tilt now. The kitchen a buzz of activity. An impatient waiter, JOHN LU, speaks above the din to GARRETT who is up to his elbows in strip paper, cookies and ink.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: Table seventeen. Conventioneers.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Reduce them to stereotypes for me. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 32.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: "Conventioneers" isn't enough? GARRETT shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: LU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sighing) All right. The man sent the first bottle of wine back. He said the nose was too herbal.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Enough said. The date? GARRETT begins scribbling down the first fortune.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: The woman is artificially tan, except for mysterious pale band on ring finger of left hand.

dialogues.speaker: GARRET
dialogues.text: Charlie Chan!

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: I see number one son impressed.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: For the lady. GARRETT hands LU first fortune.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: (reading) Stop and smell the poseurs.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: And for the gentleman... Reading second one as he writes it. Sometimes ..cheaters ..win. Mostly ..they wend up ..like ..the ..couple ..in ..the Towering ..Inferno. There. That should make for an interesting denouement.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: Day knew who?

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Denouement--outcome, ending. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 33.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: I've got one for you.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: Miffed daters stiff waiters. LU puts cookies on a small plate and exits. GARRETT yells after him.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Wisdom ain't pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETH is stretched out on the grass, a book bag nearby.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: There are a number of horrors I prefer to dating, balancing my checkbook, getting a pap smear, watching Saturday Night Live. First of all, I'm not very good at it. Dating, that is. I always say the wrong thing. I know you're supposed to act a certain way, but I can never make myself do it. You know, appearing entranced by every detail of his life or being impressed because he's in a band or owns a boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRENT is talking to BETH over wine.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: We'll be live on air, and I'll take calls off the request line,and I just know these guys are already stoned. I do the morning show. So it's like seven a.m., and I've got Jeff Spicoli calling into ask me about radio. Not how to break into the business, but how to fix them. "Yo, Dead, there's too much distortion." And I can hear it cranked in the background, but you can't tell these guys to just turn it down. TRENT looks for encouragement from BETH, but she seems uninterested. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: So anyway ..well, Fortune Cookie - 34. 39 it's boring. Shop talk. BETH realizes she's been snagged.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: No, finish. What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (unenthused) I'll play Nirvana "unplugged". They think I've fixed their radio. BETH manages a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Yeah, so...

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: No that's funny.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: No it's not. It' love the music, car alarm store people who show to my show--and who braid their eyebrows, tatoo

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: My brother is a

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Does he fit the

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: s depressing. I mean, I but I'll go out to these appearances and see the up--the people who listen it's frightening. People goatees, pierce their their necks. fan. description? He wants to go to art school.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: So he will soon.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Yeah. The conversation comes to

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: screeching halt. Have you ever played the strained- metaphor game? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 35. 39

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: The strained metaphor game. The correct answer is no, because I just made it up.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: We're giving up on natural conversational flow this early. BETH looks at her watch and gives TRENT a playful express of concern.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: We're irrigating the conversation. Replenishing it.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: How do you play?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. I just liked the title.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: All right. I've got it. The first person names two random items or concepts. The second person has to complete the strained metaphor.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Sounds challenging.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: No, the challenging version is the precise metaphor game. It's in your best interest not to confuse the two.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Can we play a sample round?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Sure. Let me think. O.K. First dates are like... TRENT scans the restaurant

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: wa glass of water. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 36. 39

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Tasteless?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I was thinking more along the lines of quenching a thirst, but I think you understand the game. So, onto round one. How about a heart and an edible garnish.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Give me a second. BETH drums her fingers on the table and thinks.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's see, the human heart, like an edible garnish, tempts the hungry who, but then chew it up and, having tasted its fruit--no make that essence--, spit it out.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Bonus points for extra strained. But I think I can see a theme here.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You do, huh? Let's create a window into your psyche. Glancing around, BETH notices a snuggly couple at a nearb table.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How about love and ..The Empire.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: That's easy. Love is an empire that conquers all.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Or that crumbles into dust?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: God, I feel like I'm on a date with the walking wounded.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: That's what Amanda--she's my roommate-- calls me. What about you? You sound awfully optimistic. "Love conquers all"-- how have you managed to keep living that lie. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 37. 39

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Healthy diet, lots of excercise.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Push ups with Santa Claus. Step class with the Easter Bunny? Wait a minute. I know you. You're the guy who's never been in love. I've heard he existed, but I never thought I'd be going out to dinner with him.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I've been in love. Well, it felt like.. I thought it was.. There was this girl who.. Jesus, I lived with a woman for three years!

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (singing) You've never been in love. You've never been in love...

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I've been deeply, head over heels, madly in like. Lots of times.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Thought so.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Do you think this somehow gives you more soul.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Not soul, necessarily, but insight. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Don't confuse being cynical with having insight.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I'm just saying, one of his spent a few nights in Heartbreak Hotel, one of us hasn't. I tell you, it makes you appreciate your own bed. BETH notices HEATH and DOUG walking into the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my God. My brother's here. I'm going to go say hi. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 38.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BETH gets up. TRENT, unsure whether he should follow, pau then stands and moves towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Heath) Pardon me for sounding forward, but you are quite possibly the most attractive man I've seen in my life.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Doug, this used to be my sister, Beth.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Hi, nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Heath and Doug, this is Trent.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: (disappointed) You look normal.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: So what are you doing here? I thought all your friends were going to Louie's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEATH is interviewed in his room. Various art projects surround him.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Just be yourself. Just be yourself. Maybe, if yourself happens to be the bass player for Oasis. Better advice--just don't be a spaz. Just don't be a spaz. Then again, I hate to set my goals too high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We return to HEATH'S awkward moment. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 39.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: We thought this place would be cool. I see those guys all the... At this moment, DEAN and CAROLYN enter the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) Ann. Hello Heath. Weren't you going to Louie's?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Change of plans.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Uh, Mom, Dean, this is Trent and ..Heath's sister ..uh.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Beth.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Yeah, Beth. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) Please call me Carolyn. The group is approached by MR. HUE.

dialogues.speaker: HUE
dialogues.text: Table for six? Everyone, save DOUG, who looks to the others for consensu gives their own variations of emphatic Nos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LU leans against the desk where Garrett is feverishly working. There is a bulletin board above GARRETT'S work station. On it, an extra large, Post It note-sized fortun tacked up. LU notices it while he's addressing Garrett. W LU speaks in the kitchen, he has no accent.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: «two crystal gazing, swimming-with-the- dolphins, New Age flakes. Make it extra crunchy. What's this... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 40.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: What it is--is intensely private, personal... Ignoring Garrett, Lu removes the pin holding the fortune.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: So why hang it up where anyone can see it?

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: (still scribbling) intimate, confidential. Because I have a general belief in the goodness of man.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: (reading) You are radiant and sublime. Old Ben Jonson's engine for time!

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: You're robbing me of my innocence, Lu.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: If there's longing inside you, if it crawls up your spine.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: I might as well take that job at the nuclear plant.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: K, L, M, two, three, one, nine. Yep, I think this could get you fired.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: I haven't sent it out. I just saw this woman in here once. This woman. More than a woman.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: She reminded you of a clock?

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: (confused) A what?

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: You call her an engine of time. Ben Johnson--is that the runner on dope? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 41.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Ben Jonson. No H. The British essayist who spoke of an engine that could keep back all clocks and make the sun forget its motion.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: Now that's a woman.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Yeah. So if I ever see her in here again, I'm risking it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEATH and DOUG look over the menus. DOUG has been positio so that she has to keep looking over her shoulder to see mother's table. She does this with annoying frequency.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You wanna split the rib appetizer?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Sounds good.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Do you feel kind of stupid here? Dressed like this? I'll bet everyone around us is checking us out, and they're telling each other about their own proms. We're like this conversation piece saving everyone who's trying to keep a conversation going, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Yeah. The two glance about a bit with this thought in mind.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be funny if I threw a glass of water in your face and yelled, "With my sister!? MY SISTER!?"

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Yeah. HEATH glances around again, this time because he thinks DOUG'S being a little loud. DOUG begins realizing she can push HEATH around.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Or you know what would be funnier? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 44 Fortune Cookie - 42.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HEATH shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you got up like you were mad, and you tried to walk out, but I grab onto one of your legs, and you're like, dragging me out. People would remember that.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You wanna do it?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: (nervously) Really?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: No. LU approaches the table. When he's in the dining room, he adopts a thick Chinese accent. He's extremely accommodati to a customer's face. Less so, in the back.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: An appetizer to start? DOUG waits for HEATH to order the appetizer they've decid on, but he's in outer space. She orders with barely-hidde annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: The ribs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROLYN stands behind the counter at Les Video.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Well, the nice thing about dating someone for a long time is that all that silly stuff you go through at first--you know, nervously laughing when you don't know if something he says is supposed to be a joke or fretting about the attempted good night kiss--it's all behind you. No more game playing. I can just tell what Dean is thinking most of the time. And the same goes in reverse, which is good, because I don't know what I'm thinking sometimes.  45 Fortune Cookie - 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROLYN and DEAN haven't even picked up their menus yet.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: San Francisco?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Six Figures.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: California?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Iowa.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (attempting enthusiasm) Oh, Dean, that's great. Congratulations. Boy this calls for a celebration. Is there a new title in it, too?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'll be The Man.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Convenient.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I'll say. But it's not a done deal yet.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: But they've offered it?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: They've offered it, but I'm playing it cool, which for an accountant means I'm not high-fiving anyone in the hallways.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Well what are you waiting for? It's what you've wanted.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: There are other considerations.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Such as? LU is passing by the table. DEAN catches his attention. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45  45 46 Fortune Cookie - 44.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Could you get us a bottle of wine, please?

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: It would be my privilege. Would you like to see the list?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Just get us anything white and Californian. LU nods and continues towards kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: (to himself) A glass of Ronald Reagan, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: So what are these other considerations? DEAN looks at CAROLYN for a pregnant moment before responding.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: What yard line my 49ers season tickets will be on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRENT and BETH have their meals in front of them. TRENT u chopsticks, expertly. BETH observes this feat with a mixt of awe and suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You're scaring me.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (confused) How so?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: The rose. You ordered the wine in French. You're like Edward Scissorhands with those chopsticks. Next, I'm afraid you're going to stick this flower in your mouth and tell me you know how to tango.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: You don't?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Trent Kennedy, are you a player? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 45. 46

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Player? Like Warren Beatty is a player?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Player like Warren Beatty calls you for advice.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I think it's my job.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Suave is your job?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Sort of. Never being at a loss for words. It's kind of like dating.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You go out a lot?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Not really. You?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Full moons. Usually I'll line up someone to watch Haley's Comet with me.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: So, if you're the broken heart expert, tell me what it's like--this love thang.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Oh it comes in stages. You start with infatuation. You hear yourself saying things like, "Sure, I'd love to go see Pat Metheney with you."

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Yikes.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. This is still the good part. For an all-too-brief splendorous blip in time, it hits you. You feel complete for the first time ever ..even though you didn't know you were missing anything. Every song on the radio becomes "Ode to The Two of Us." You're not sure if the planet has continued to spin outside of your bedroom. You burn through more candles than the Little House On The Prairie. You have playful arguments over whether to name your unconceived daughter (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 46.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BETH (cont'd) Nena or Emma. Gradually the line between you and the other person begins to blur. Mere loss of identity serves as a precursor to outright slavery.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Are we still in the good part?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Until one day, one of you wakes up and decides it's not right. It's not perfect. It's time to move on. BETH stops abruptly and takes a drink of water.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I've heard something about swooning.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: That's from lack of oxygen. Side-effect of rushing in where angels fear to tread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG wears her cheerleading practice clothes.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I think it took me until eighth grade to completely figure out boys. Then, once I had, I was embarrassed it took me that long. I mean, they're that simple. What I figured out was that, if you want one, you make him the center of the universe. Everything revolves around him. His day. His football practice. The little bruise on his elbow. The kind of car he wants to drive someday. Then, during my sophomore year--I think it was pretty soon after my boyfriend at the time, Bobby Snowden, missed my Dad's funeral because of an Aerosmith concert--I decided I wanted the world to revolve around me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LU delivers the rib appetizer to DOUG and HEATH. DOUG ser herself, but HEATH only watches.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to have any?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Uh, no. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 Fortune Cookie - 47.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Well, I'm a vegetarian.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: A vegetarian? I thought you said the rib appetizer sounded good.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I meant it sounded good ..for you. If that's what you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: We could have gotten something else.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I don't really like Chinese food.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Why did you say you wanted to come here?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: It's fine. Really. I can find something I'll eat. DOUG is clearly exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Look, could we trade seats?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Um, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Thanks. The pair gets up and changes seats. The process is awkwar All the dishes and glasses have to be traded as well. Onc the process is complete, it's clear that DOUG is looking HEATH'S shoulder while they're talking.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Why did you want to change?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Why did you want to trade seats? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 48. 48 DOUG takes a moment to decide whether to tell HEATH. She' keeping a constant watch over HEATH'S shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Dean's spare glass eye? I think it's really a ring which means he's going to pop the question to Mom tonight, and I want to see her reaction if he does.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Oh. What'll she say if he does?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm almost positive.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Not many people get to see one of their parents get asked that question.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I wish I had a video camera.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Do you get to see your real Dad much?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Nope. He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: God, I'm sorry. It's just that.. Well, I don't know. It's just that all my friends' parents are divorced. I just assumed...

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: No sweat. Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEAN'S cubicle has photographs tacked up around it. Most of little league teams he has coached, but there's also a large one of CAROLYN, and a small, school-picture-sized o of DOUG.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: You know how, sometimes, something that just starts as a little misunderstanding gets repeated and changed so much, that it becomes, like, a new reality. That's what's happened with the story of my near wedding. I was twenty-seven at the time, and I had been dating this woman for seven years. All of our friends thought (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 49.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DEAN (cont'd) of us as married anyway, so eventually we decided we might as well make it official. It was a huge deal. We're both from the same hometown, and I think we invited everybody. I told Carolyn how awful it is for someone to get stood up at the alter. I guess it's the way I told the story--she always assumed I was the one who got stood up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROLYN and DEAN finish giving LU their order.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: And the chicken lemon grass, ..and he'd like some more water.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: How spicy you want your food?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: On a scale of one to ten...

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: Ten being spicy?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Ten being spicy. Make mine a two and his a sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: Very good.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I've got it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Got what?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I know where I've met Doug's date.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I wish you'd at least call her Ann.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Ann's date. I coached him. It must have been eight or nine years ago.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Was he good? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 50. 50

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Played him in right field.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Right field.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Least skill-intensive position. Frequent spaz repository.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Dean!

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: But I know why I remember him now. I mean, I've coached a lot of kids. But there was this play, I don't think I'll ever forget. Something you just don't see in most lifetimes. We were in the playoffs, and we were into extra innings. We had a one run lead, but whoever we were playing had runners at second and third with two outs. Their batter hits a line shot out to right. I figure the game is over. That kid, Heath, he did have some speed, but he couldn't catch a cold. Anyway, he runs this fly ball down, dives...

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Catches it, and you win the game? The Rocky theme music plays.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Well that's what it looked like from where I was sitting. And from where the ump was to, because he called the batter out which meant we won. So everyone is celebrating. The team is throwing their hats in the air, and I spot Heath talking to the umpire. The next thing I know, we've lost the game.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: He's told the umpire that he trapped the ball. He didn't catch it on the fly, so the two runners scored.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: So you've always resented this kid? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 5 Fortune Cookie - 51.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: No, I've always admired him. I don't think I've ever seen an eight-year-old do anything more noble. If I ever have a child, I hope, well first off, I hope he has better hands, but after that, I hope he's got balls that big.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Dean Jeffries, you gross me out, and I truly love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRENT walks into the bathroom and finds HEATH sitting on floor. TRENT, self-consciously, goes about his business.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Date going well?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I don't get it. I don't understand why the nicer I am, the meaner she gets. How long do you think I'll have to stay here before she'll leave?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Niceness is overrated. Something they say they want, but in the end...

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (thinking better of expounding on this theory) Look, do you have any anecdotes?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Any what?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Anecdotes. Little stories to fall back on.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I don't know. They have to be your stories, but don't tell her about leading the county in rushing yardage or about (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 51 52 53 Fortune Cookie - 52.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TRENT (cont'd) all the babes that call you in the middle of the night.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: The best anecdotes..hmm. At first they sound self-depreciating, but used properly, they reveal your sensitive side. They show how vulnerable you are. If that doesn't work, make fun of the fattest kid in your school. HEATH looks at TRENT with something approaching shock.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's a joke. I tell you, though, it's like an Olympic event. You get better the more you practice.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Sort of ironic, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (laughs) Ironic? You are your sister's brother.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: It's ironic because, it seems like, if a guy was really good at it, he would never get enough practice to become Mr. Gold Medalist Dater. As the implications of that statement bloom on TRENT'S fa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Carolyn reapplying make-up in the mirror. As she t to maintain a stoic face, she breaks down. A tear runs do her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEATH returns to the table. The meal has arrived. DOUG ha already begun eating. The only thing waiting for HEATH is heaping bowl of white rice. DOUG works on some extravagan and colorful dish.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Hurry, we wouldn't want your meal to get cold. HEATH sits down and begins eating. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 53.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what made you become a vegetarian? DOUG shovels in an especially large morsel of meat.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Just ..I don't know.. became one.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I mean, do you just not like meat? Or do you not believe in killing animals? Or are you just into the health factor?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: None of those I guess. I used to eat meat. I liked it fine. I just don't anymore. I'm not really much of a vegetarian either. I don't like vegetables all that much.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: So what happened? Did you get locked in a slaughterhouse or something?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: This is a really bad anecdote. Makes me look stupid.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I'll tell you, but you won't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Try me.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: It's because of my pen pal. DOUG stares at HEATH uncomprehendingly.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In eighth grade, Mrs. Russell signed us all up for pen pals in honors English. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You were in that class?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Yeah. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 54. 53

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Mine was from France. I think I wrote her twice.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Mine was from Somalia. His name is Achmad Housbhenni, and we still write every once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Wow, really? And he convinced you to become a vegetarian?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: It's not quite that simple. He's not even a vegetarian. He just wrote to me a lot about being hungry. All of his letters were about meals he had or questions about what I eat. After a while, I started thinking about what I was eating every time I put food into my mouth, imagining how Achmed would be enjoying this burrito more than me, or the poetry he would write if he ever got his hands on one Big Mac. I started reading about the famine, what caused it, the relief efforts, all that, and one of the things they kept mentioning, one of the reasons the U.S. couldn't export more grain, is because we use it to feed livestock.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Well, doesn't that balance out? Wouldn't we be eating that grain if we weren't eating those cows?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
