dialogues.text: Yes and no. See, it takes like three times as much energy and land to produce the same amount of food as meat as it does food as grain, but in first world countries, that doesn't seem to bother anyone. We can afford it. In third world countries, it's a different story.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: So that's when you became a vegetarian?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Not right away, but after a few months of picturing little kids with bloated bellies every time I put meat in my mouth, I just sort of gave into it. I (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 54 Fortune Cookie - 55.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HEATH (cont'd) guess I guess I'm not really making much of a difference. I never really try to convince people to join me. HEATH puts a forkful of rice into his mouth. DOUG hesitat before resuming her meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRENT and BETH are finishing up their meals.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: So it's your turn to pick the novel for the book club next time. Do you know what you're going to pick?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Ladder of Years, I think. It's the newest Ann Tyler book. Have you read it?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: No, I've read The Accidental Tourist, though.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I am impressed. I can't believe you're the same guy who calls people at six in the morning pretending to be a sex-toy salesman.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: That's not me. That's the ninety one point seven guy. I'm the one who does "Strange Body Sounds."

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Forgive me. I'm still surprised.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: That I can read?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Not that you can read, that you're well- read. There's a big difference.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, it's the result of a ..uh, complicated childhood. TRENT waits a beat for BETH to bite; she doesn't. He proc in his "anecdote" mode.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I was a kid, I was afraid of bees. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 56. 54

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Bees?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Yeah, bees. I fell into a hive once. Got stung like eight times. After that, you couldn't get me to go outside.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I don't think bee-phobia qualifies you for "complicated childhood" status.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I'm talking for a couple years. Anyway, after school each day, I had to go over to my Meemaw's house.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Meemaw?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Queen mother.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (laughs) So, Meemaw lived near this pond and all these dragonflies would be buzzing around her yard, but I didn't know what dragonflies were. I thought they were giant bees. LU approaches the table.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: Would you like these plates cleared?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Sure. I was afraid to go outside, and Meemaw didn't have a TV, or it was always broken, I can't remember. But she did have Dad's complete Hardy Boys collection. That's when I started reading. I think I read them all two or three times.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You were afraid of dragonflies? That's why you became an avid reader? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 57.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: That, and my endless quest for truth. Hey, could you believe Randall chose The Hobbit for the group last month. Did he think we were all in sixth grade? Did you see the "I Break For Unicorns" bumper sticker on his car?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: The Hobbit is a great book. There is an awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean it. A classic. LU, wearing an expression of amusement, takes the plates into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LU sets the dishes down before moving over to GARRETT'S station. GARRETT is blow drying a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: Table nine. Looks like a first date.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Him?

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: A regular.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Her?

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: Unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: I'll see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEAN and CAROLYN ignore their food. They hold hands acros the table.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I don't know if I ever told you this, but you were supposed to be Gerald's account.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Gerald?--the one that names his pencils? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 58. 56

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: No, that's Albert. Gerald's the one who does that dance, the deduction dance, right at midnight every April fifteenth. He uses staplers as castanets.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: So what happened?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I saw you. You were in our lobby. Apparently some old timer waiting next to you suggested you not make any financial decisions without consulting your husband first. As I walked through, you were listing orifices in which he might have better luck introducing his theory. Gerald was next in line for new accounts, but I traded him the Madison Beer Garden account for the privilege of working with the lovely and vocal proprietress of Les Video.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (impressed) You traded a sports bar for me?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I'm a big believer in long-term, consistent performers.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: You're so smart. And sweet. I appreciate how slow you took things in the beginning. I didn't think I was ready to get back out there, play the dating game.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Uh, Babe. That wasn't sweetness. That was fear.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Dean, what's going to happen to us?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Let's see. You're easy. Twenty years from now you'll be retired--if you keep putting that money into tax-sheltered annuities like I told you. There'll be little Les Video franchises across the state. You'll live in a lake house, spoil your grandchildren. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 59.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: By myself?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Oh, Carolyn, you can have anyone you want. 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The check and the fortune cookies have arrived on TRENT a BETH'S table.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: What does yours say?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I thought you weren't supposed to tell anyone.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Those are wishes. Fortunes you're actually supposed to tell. TRENT breaks open his cookie and reads his fortune.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (reading) "He who is lonely is he who is always..."

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: That's it. I think the ending got torn off. Makes sense if you add "in bed."

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I always thought you were supposed to add “after sex." TRENT reads to himself.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: It doesn't make sense that way.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Yes it does. Think of after as a verb, not an adverb. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 60.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (reading) He who is lonely is he who is always after sex. Oh, yeah. (He lets' that sink in.) So what about yours? What does yours say?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Mine's bizarre.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Let me hear it.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (reading) Abba Gold thirteen colon four.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Sounds like something from the Bible: Book of Abba, chapter thirteen, verse four.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: If I read it, do you think I'll be Bjorn again?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: You know, this is why not everyone is given a radio show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEATH and DOUG have finished their dinners. DOUG'S plate clean. DOUG still has a half bowl of white rice in front him.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: So what made you ask me out?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Well it's not like we'd ever really talked.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: True. Do you remember when we had that square dancing unit in P.E. in junior high. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 61. 58

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Square dancing: has anything ever been named so perfectly?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Anyway, remember how they would number all the girls, then number all the boys and you were supposed to find the person with the number that matched and that was your partner.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Well, if one of us happened to luck out and draw someone recognizably female and then refused to trade, the football players would threaten to dismember us. So, even under this outwardly egalitarian system, the bold and the beautiful still always ended up together. There's only one time I can remember that it didn't play out like that. You ended up with this dork who had grown six inches in fourteen months. He could hardly stand upright let alone swing to the left. Anyway, some walking Coke machine tapped this lucky fellow on the shoulder and gave him a quick lesson on social Darwinism. So this guy's already walking back down to dance with Paleolithic woman, but you grabbed his hand, and told the football player to get a life.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I said "get a life"? Ugh.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I've wanted to ask you out ever since then.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: That was you?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: (indignant) No. No, that wasn't me. No ..it was my best friend, Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: God, I don't even remember that. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 62.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Ryan does. He was pretty thrilled when I said I was going with you. You're the one cheerleader he refuses to make fun of.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (facetiously) I'm honored. LU approaches the table. He begins clearing dishes.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: Could I tempt you with any dessert? Perhaps a Hershey Bar for the gentleman?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I'd like one.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: But of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LU enters GARRETT'S sanctum.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: Table seven: first and last date for Veronica and Jughead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEAN continues his interview.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: When you're counting down the days until you hit forty and you still haven't been married, you can't help but hear the whispers. I know what they're saying, "He sure is patient." "What a full life he must lead to not need a woman in it." I can't lie. It hurts. Actually, the mistake people usually make is that they think any guy who makes it this long is too picky or fears commitment, but that's not me at all. I fear ending up with the wrong person. I really want to get this right the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEAN and CAROLYN continue ignoring their food. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 63. 61

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: We'll rack up a bunch of frequent flyer miles. It won't be so bad. A couple weekends a month--we could do that.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Maybe..at the beginning. But then some weekend we plan on seeing each other, you'll have some major deadline, so we'll skip that and tell each other, you know, it's okay--it's just one weekend. After a while all that time in airports and on planes will get tiring, and besides there's that "hot little number" in acquisitions that's always dropping hints.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: "Hot little number?" Is that an accountant joke.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (chuckling) No. Strike that. You're a better man than that, Dean. It'll be some smart, attractive woman who recognizes the same things in you that I do.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: You're being bad.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I'm being realistic. Look every teenaged girl at some point in her life, falls for a boy on the other side of the lake, and no matter what promises are made: I'll write, I'll see you next summer, I'll wait for you. It never works. Long Distance Relationship is one of the world's great oxymorons.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Then what do you propose?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Nothing, Dean. I'm very happy for you, but I can't help being sad for us.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: How sad?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: What? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 64.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: How sad? I mean, if I got down on my knee right here, handed you a ring, what would you say?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Don't be silly, Dean. I wouldn't want you to. After a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Then who are we kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRENT and BETH ride in TRENT'S car.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Another game?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: C'mon, be a sport.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: A sport? Gee, Pops, I'll try.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: That's my girl. This one's called "Surreal Date." Here's how it works. You get two choices. You pick of them. By the time we're finished, I'll have a complete psychological profile on you.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: First, your date. Woody Allen or Sylvester Stallone.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I don't suppose Ralph Fiennes is behind curtain number three.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: He is, but he's feeling surly, reclusive. It's the Woodman or Rocky tonight.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I don't like these choices. I don't like what either one of them says about me. But I see what you're doing. They're so (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 65. 62 BETH (cont'd) different, you think picking one over the other defines my character.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Hardly. Honestly, I have a tough time remembering which is which.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Stallone and Woody Allen?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Both of them are Oscar winning screenwriters. They've dated some of the hottest babes in show business?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Mia Farrow is a hot babe?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Frank Sinatra thought so. Okay, what else? Woody Allen visited Dallas to promote Everything You Wanted To Know About Sex. Sly had sex after auditioning for Dallas.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Who even says "hot babe?"

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Charlie Sheen. Rod Stewart.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Fine company you're keeping. TRENT begins singing the Jeopardy music.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're still expecting an answer? He reaches the conclusion of the tune.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, Stallone.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Surprising. Now, attending a Planet Hollywood opening or playing in the MTV Rock And Jock softball game?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Speaking of which, where are we heading right now? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 63 Fortune Cookie - 66.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (shaking head) Eh, eh, eh, eh. No getting out of this.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Planet Hollywood, I guess. Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: My house. Now. Sly's ignoring you..

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Hold on. Time out. We're going where?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I just need to run in and give Rover some medicine.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Oh? And I had completely forgotten--I'm expecting a call from my grandmother. Maybe you ought to drop me off. Do we have a few minutes before Rover goes into cardiac arrest?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I'll drop you off if you want, but I swear there's no devious motive. You could wait in the car if you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll come in. I've never seen a real mirrored ceiling before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty foil wrapper from a Hershey Bar rests on the tab Half of the bar is on a plate in front of HEATH. The othe half minus a couple sections rests on a plate in front of DOUG. They work on their chocolate throughout the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: No, you see, that's the thing that drives my Mom nuts. I have no ambition. There's no great thing I want to do. I don't want to run a corporation or dance on Broadway. I want to be an absorber. See the world. Take things in.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: That's an ambition. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 67. 63

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I'll look in the paper for any openings for absorbers.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Well, there are travel writers, museum guides.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: But that's not absorbing. That's the opposite of absorbing--things going out instead of things coming in.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: You're saying those would be a good jobs for an exuder.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Hmmm. You're right, you don't have much ambition.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I told you. But it's not like I mind working, you know--waiting tables, dealing blackjack, bottlecapping at a brewery.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I don't think they do that any more. Robots and all.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I just have a more European way of thinking about it. You know, where you work to live rather than live to work

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Yeah, those whimsical Germans.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: No, like the Spanish or Italians. Work for a couple hours in the morning. Take a three hour lunch, maybe a nap. Sunbathe. Come back to work for a couple hours in the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Overthrow the fascist regime that's taken power while you've been getting tan. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 68. 63

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You don't approve. You think I sound hedonistic.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: No, no. I think it sounds great. I hope you're able to do it. Lu approaches the table, but a customer scoots out his ch causing the fortune cookies he's carrying for HEATH and D to pop into the air. He catches them without dropping the but it's obvious he no longer knows which cookie goes to which diner.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: So what about you? Do you have ambition.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: (facetiously) Oh, yeah, me? I'm going to make millions. Swimming pools, movie stars...

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Doing what?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I'm going to be an avant garde artist.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Oh we are talking big bucks.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: You know what I hate, maybe more than anything.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Racism, poverty...

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Furniture stores that sell paintings.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I was going to say that.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Have you seen them. They set up those fake little rooms. You've got your taupe love seat. You've got your taupe coffee table. Then, you've got some sorry fruit bowl still life displayed in a taupe (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 69. 63 HEATH (cont'd) frame. Great art doesn't match your couch.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: See, you've got passion. I don't have anything I'm passionate about.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Don't even get me started on the stuff they hang up in hotel rooms. DOUG picks up her cookie.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Do you know the deal with the fortune cookies here?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (adopting a very serious tone) They always come true. No, just kidding. But they are supposed to be original. They write a new one for everyone who comes in.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Wow. They both crack open their cookies.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What does yours say?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: (reading) Lyle Lovett, Billy Joel, Ric Ocasek--you never know who's going to win a Grammy.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: That's just weird.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Let's hear yours.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (reading) What do these things have in common: lawnmower, revolving door, sap? HEATH shrugs. DOUG shakes her head in wonder.  Fortune Cookie - 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The food in front of DEAN and CAROLYN is half-eaten and getting cold.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: So let me get this straight. You don't even think there's a point in trying it out, seeing if we could make it work. I don't think that's fair.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: What's not fair? I'm just saying it never works.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Well the first thing that's not fair, is that you're saying it won't work out because I'll be too busy or that I'll find someone new. You're the busiest woman I know. Sorry, the busiest person. You never slow down, and it's this curse, that all the things that I love about you- -the way you save receipts when we go to movies so you can write them off; the way that, when you get an idea in your head for the store, you can go ten minutes without hearing a word I say; even the way you fax me love notes--these same things are what will keep us apart.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: You would never sell that store.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: How could you even ask me to?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I'm not asking you to. My point is, it's more than a store for you. It's validation. Proof that you can make it without a husband. Well I think you've proved it to yourself and to your in- laws. You said yourself, you don't see pity on their faces anymore. So who are you proving it to now? Blockbuster is offering you enough money that you could open a new store, twice the size anywhere you wanted... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 71. 64

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Not here. They said I can't open one here. This is where Ann goes to school.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: For a few more months. Still, you act like the offer is an insult.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I'm beginning to see the disadvantages of having your boyfriend doing the books.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: What are your views on love? This is where LU approaches the table to clear dishes.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: (noticing the leftovers) Was there something wrong with the food. We will gladly execute the chef.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (flustered) No. It was fine. Can we get it in a bag. LU glances distatefully at the picked at remains. LU exits.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: My views on love?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Maybe we should have talked about this earlier, but, what I'm saying is, where does love rank? We say it all the time. "I love you." For some people it's this consuming thing. It's like a drug, makes them think in sonnet form. For some people it's companionship and comfort. Where does it stand with you?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Dean, this is difficult. I'm not sure you should be asking me this.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Maybe it should have been a first date question. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 72. 64

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Would've been a short first date.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I still want to know. I think I need to know.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: It ranks high.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: How high?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Very high. CAROLYN looks to Dean to see if the answer will suffice. expression indicates that it won't.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Below motherhood. Is that what you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Where in comparison to the free enterprise system?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: You're being mean.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: But I'm serious. Where do we rank in comparison to your store.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: You see, you want to make this an easy comparison--you or the store, but it's not that simple. It's not about the store. It's about me. The store is independence. It's self worth. Look, I married Tom straight out of high school. I went straight from being somebody's daughter to somebody's girlfriend to somebody's wife to somebody's widow. Opening that store was the first thing I did completely on my own.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: So if both the store and me caught on fire, and you only had one bucket of water... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 73.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Well, Dean. You could roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We return to TRENT'S interview scene.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Most of the women I date? Let's see, if there's one recurring trait, I would have to say that they're all fun. All fun girls. Definitely out to have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRENT and BETH arrive at Trent's house. They round a shru or wall, or similar barrier and run into a tipsy TERESA w is fishing her earrings out of the mailbox.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Teresa ..this is a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: Found them! TERESA turns and holds up the earrings. Only now does she notice BETH. She tries to cover.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: «and you're right. They'll be perfect for my audition.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Someone's doing Bus Stop?

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Nothing. TRENT opens the front door of his house and ushers BETH inside.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (to Beth) Let me just make sure she makes it out to the cab.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Chivalry is not dead. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 74.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TRENT shakes his head and escorts TERESA out to the cab.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: Sorry I didn't make it earlier.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: Is that going anywhere? TERESA gestures towards the apartment. TRENT shrugs. They reach the waiting cab.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll be up for a while. If you want to come by afterwards. You've got my number in that little black book of yours, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We return to BETH'S interview scene.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I think my problem, on dates, is that I think of them as automatically confrontational. Let's face it, guys have a different set of goals by which they measure a date's success. I've been thinking about giving up on men. Maybe become romantically linked with, say, my refrigerator, or follow Amanda's advice and find love online. At least at the end of the evening, I won't have to hear the phrase, "I'll call you." Translation-- we'll bump into each other several months from now, you'll be wearing sweats and have a cold sore, and I'll introduce you to my new supermodel fiance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRENT enters his house.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: So, Stallone's rented a couple movies for the limo ride. He gives you the choice of either Rocky Three or...

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Okay, that's enough. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 Fortune Cookie - 75.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TRENT continues walking towards the kitchen while Beth be examining the books on the shelves--not the ones left out her perusal.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: «Stop Or My Mom Will Shoot. Whatever you say.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: So you're a jewelry consultant. Very impressive.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: She's a friend. We hang out sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: There's a term for that. BETH continues examining the book collection

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Norman Mailer? You like Norman Mailer.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You don't?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: As far as corny, narcissistic, adolescent- sounding, sexist writers full of glib schtick on highbrow topics, he's not bad. Oh look, you have his entire oeuvre.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, we can't all aspire to Ann Tyler status.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: What's wrong with Ann Tyler?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She's boring.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Where is this phantom dog of yours? Here Rover! Here Rover! TRENT returns to the living room with an obviously sick kitten wrapped in a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Sic her boy. Attack! The sight of the sick kitten melts BETH a bit. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 76.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I think it's against some law, naming a cat Rover. Fines are involved.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Not Rover--Ro VAIR. He's named for the French poet.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) RoVAIR?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Man, you don't let anything slide. Can you help me here.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: What do I need to do?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Just wrap up his legs here in the blanket.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Like this?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's good. The maneuvering and repositioning TRENT and BETH undertak order to medicate the cat forces them into close physical proximity to each other.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is not the most pleasant part of his day. He's like one of those Aliens trying to claw out of someone's chest. Okay, Ro-- it's time for your Shirley Temple. TRENT withdraws a small bottle of pinkish medicine and a dropper that he tries to force into Rover's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (singing) "On the good ship, Lollypop. It's a something, something, to the candy shop."

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Sweet trip. How old is he? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 77.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. I just found him out in the alley going through my garbage. I don't think he comes from a very good family. TRENT successfully gets ROVER to swallow his drops. He si down on a couch and pets the kitten while Beth wanders ba to the bookcases.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You have every Doctor Seuss book.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (slightly embarrassed) Not every one.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: What are you missing?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: The Cat In The Hat Comes Back. I don't go for sequels.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You're so cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEATH and DOUG drive towards the dance. DOUG appears distracted or upset.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I'm sorry you didn't get to see Dean propose.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: It's not just that. They didn't look happy.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: My parents never look happy. I think that's just part of being old.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you should see them together most of the time. It's like they can't keep their hands off each other. It always embarrasses Troy. The present tense mention of Troy seems to bother HEATH.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. That's rude. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 78.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: It's not that. I just got this mental picture of my mom kissing some strange man. HEATH shudders.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Well Dean's cool. And I want Mom to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I think that's what makes you different.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Different from what.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: From the stereotype.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What stereotype?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: From the "Girls who could get by on their looks" stereotype.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: In case you were wondering. I'm not taking this as a compliment.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'm sorry. That does sound bad. All I mean is that it must be a challenge. Everybody wants to make you happy, somehow or in some way. I think it would be hard to keep from thinking the world revolved around you.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What makes you think I don't? Because I danced with your friend in junior high?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: No. More than that. That you're excited for your Mom. That you don't care if she embarrasses you in front of your boyfriend. That you actually try hard in Trig. I don't know, partly it's because you said you'd come to this with me. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 Fortune Cookie - 79.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HEATH pulls into the parking lot of the hotel where the p is taking place. Other couples, similarly attired, move p their windows towards the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Let's not.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Let's not go to the dance.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I don't get it. Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I just don't feel like it.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: You don't feel like it.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Have you ever been to these things? The band is always lame. It costs too much. A bunch of drunks stepping on your feet.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: To answer your question, no, I haven't been to one. Four years of high school. Zero formal dances. You're the first person--well, no, your mom is the first person--you're the second person ever to see me in a tuxedo. These things may be stupid, but I'd like the chance to find out for myself.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: We could do something else. HEATH sighs and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I don't know exactly what your problem is. I don't know if you're embarrassed to be seen with me. Maybe you're afraid you'll see Troy with someone else. Maybe you really do hate dances. But I wish you would have just said no when I asked you.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: It's not... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 72 Fortune Cookie - 80.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go in. I'm gonna talk to my friends. Get my picture taken. See if anyone'll dance with me. You can either wait here, or, if you want, I'll give you a ride home. Whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Just take me home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dishes have been cleared away from in front of CAROLY and DEAN. The check and the fortune cookies sit untouched a small tray beside them.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: So that's it. I guess I'll tell them I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: You have to.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: They want me out there in a month.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Then let's make it a good month.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: You just want to call it off right here.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: One year. It has a certain mathematical perfection to it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (sadly, hopefully) And we all know how important that is. It does gives us the rest of tonight.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: So what do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: What's playing at the Majestic?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I have no idea. I haven't been there for.. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 81.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: A year.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's right. A year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Return to DOUG'S interview scene.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Mom doesn't know this, but I did go out with a college guy for a couple months. I think those were the months right after my lobotomy. The only difference I could ever figure out is that he didn't ask me to wear his letter jacket. The thing about guys--and I can't decide if this is a minus or a plus--is that they're predictable. You know exactly what they're going to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEATH and DOUG ride in silence.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Heath, I want to tell you something. First of all, I wouldn't be embarrassed to go to the dance with you. Not at all. When we left tonight. I had every intention of going through with it.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Go through with it?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I don't mean it like that. The truth is, Troy called me before you came to pick me up. He wants to get back together--after tonight. He already had a date.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: So you don't want to screw it up by going in there with me.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: No. That's not it. I was going to make him jealous. To punish him. To show everyone I wasn't just sitting around waiting for him to come back to me. And I was using you to do that. And that was okay when you were just some guy I didn't (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 82.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOUG (cont'd) really know. Somebody who shocked me into going with him.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: As long as we're confessing. I was counting on that.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: On what?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: On the surprise factor ..when I asked you.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Good strategy.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: So what made you change your mind?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: About the dance?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You got too real.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: My bad.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I don't have to be home yet.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Where do you want to go?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LU brings the uncracked fortune cookies from CAROLYN and DEAN'S table and sets them down in front of GARRETT who continues to work on new fortunes.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: Not even opened. Breaks my heart.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Now I know how the guys who write for Playboy feel. Whose were they? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75 76 Fortune Cookie - 83.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: The couple breaking up.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: What insight did I offer? LU cracks open the fortune cookies.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: "Sometimes one plus zero equals more than one plus one." And... "By the time Glenn Campbell got to Phoenix, his girl back home had placed a personal ad." Garrett, You are cold-blooded.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Hey, wisdom ain't always pretty. LU tears up the strips and throws them in GARRETT'S trash can.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing? I can still use those.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: You can't recycle people's destinies.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: You don't really believe that what I write back here has any bearing on what happens out there in the real world.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: Look, my grandfather never opens his fortune cookie. He says he doesn't need the advice it offers or want the future it holds.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: You're scaring me, Lu. You don't believe that if you step on a crack you break your mother's back.

dialogues.speaker: LU
dialogues.text: No. That's just stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETH continues to rummage through TRENT'S book shelves. R wanders about. BETH pulls a book off a shelf. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 Fortune Cookie - 84.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: What's this? "Everything I Know About Sex" by Trent Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Open it up.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Blank pages. BETH laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: It was a gag gift.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: What was her name?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Mom.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Kinky. Returning her attention to the book shelves.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, most of the time, I don't mind being a destitute graduate student. I just don't need that much money to be happy, but this makes me jealous. All my books have due dates stamped inside.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I think half my paycheck goes straight to Book 'Em Dano's.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I love that store.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: No string quartets playing on the staircase. No croissant peddling cappuccino bar. No events for single lit lovers. Just floor-to-ceiling books. God bless ‘em. BETH pulls a book off the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: A Prayer For Owen Meaney--This is my favorite book of all time. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 85. 76

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Really? Mine too. Well, actually, I've got like seven favorite books of all time. Check out the flap.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (opening book, reading) "Mr. Dead, Read less. Live more. John Irving." Wow.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: They were interviewing him on our AM affiliate, so I put on Freebird--this was when we were still classic rock and I was Trent "The Grateful Dead" Kennedy. BETH doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was a joke. Anyway, I ran across the hall with a tape recorder and got him to sign my book and do a promo.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: A promo?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Yeah, I play it every once in a while for a laugh. It's him saying, "I'm John Irving, and whenever I'm in town, I rock harder on one oh one point seven." Afterwards, I get all these calls wanting to know if John Irving plays bass for Primus.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You don't strike me as the DJ-type, Trent.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: That's what my station manager was saying the other day.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I just figured DJs were obnoxious all the time. On air and off air.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: It's the voice. In high school, I went through career placement, and they said I could do this or sing bass for the Oak Ridge Boys. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 77 78 Fortune Cookie - 86.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The pager in BETH'S purse starts beeping.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Uh.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Do you need to use a phone?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Yeah, can I?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: There's one right there ..or you could use the one in the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Great. Which way?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (smiling knowingly) Straight back.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETH sits on the edge of TRENT'S bed to use the phone. Sh does actually glance at the ceiling to make sure there is mirror on it. The candles above the bed visibly concern h She dials.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: It's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMANDA sits at a computer while talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: This is your bail out call.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: It sounds like you won't be rushing home.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I probably should...

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: But? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 87. 78

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: He has his own copy of Horton Hears A Hoo.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You're at his house!

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Couldn't be helped.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Mmmhhhmmm. Could be worse. You could be in a virtual hot tub with the fourteen other members of the Andy Griffith Online fan club.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I hadn't looked at it that way. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROLYN continues her interview.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: There was this guy who asked me out every day for two weeks. He was probably close to seventy, and he kept renting the raciest things we had in the store, anything with the word erotic on the cover. He would rent the maximum six tapes at a time then return them the next day and rent six more. I'd ask him if he enjoyed the movies, and he'd say, "Not as much as I would if you'd watch them with me." Then he'd laugh this little evil laugh. Turns out, he was dubbing portions of "The Greatest Story Ever Told" over every steamy scene. I had to take him to small claims court. But I remember, very clearly, missing the daily proposition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROLYN and DEAN sit in the front seat of Carolyn's car. see a cutaway of some schlocky, Roger Cormanesque B-movie the drive- in screen.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: It's not exactly The African Queen. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 88.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I don't know. The swamp monster has a certain Kate Hepburn quality. Doing Katherine Hepburn

dialogues.speaker: DEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now I mean it! I will devour you! Laughing, CAROLYN attempts to hold DEAN'S hand. DEAN (cont'd) Watch it sister. That's a little friendly for a first date, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Sorry, forgot. I really couldn't believe you had the nerve to take me to a drive- in on our first date.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Why's that? Do you have some unwholesome memories you want to share?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Not at all. We didn't have a drive-in in my hometown. It's just the reputation, you know, drive-ins equal hanky panky.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Not for me. My oldest brother used to take all five us here when we were kids. I'll always think of drive-ins as John Wayne, Coke down my shorts, and a trip to the swing set when the kissing started.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: You know what I remember most about our first date?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: My punctuality?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: No, though that was impressive, but what I'm talking about is that you didn't whine about me wanting to go dutch.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I'm an accountant. Of course I didn't whine. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 81 82 83 Fortune Cookie - 89.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Well you'd be surprised. You know I didn't date much, hardly at all, before you, but every time I tried to pay, it was like I was asking my date to get a vasectomy. Like somehow I was neutering him by not letting him pay. It showed you were confident. There's nothing more attractive than confidence.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Now, in all fairness to those weenies you went out with before, it is a tough call. I mean, I asked you out. It only stands to reason that I should pay.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you asked me out? I asked out you out.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: You asked me if I could come over to go over your books with you. That's not a date.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I mentioned food.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: You asked me if I liked Pringles. I'm the one who suggested we make a night of it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I'm glad you did. CAROLYN leans over onto DEAN'S shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Do you think I should let my buddies out of the trunk yet.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Make ‘em suffer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEATH'S car pulls up in front of the coffee shop. As it d the rumble of a jet drowns out all other sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We return to HEATH'S interview scene (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 90. 83

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I think my biggest fear in all this is being a sap. You know that little red headed girl that Charlie Brown has been after for, uh, let's see ..eternity. Everybody knows it ain't gonna happen. It makes you want to scream at him. Charlie hang it up. She doesn't know you're alive. But what can you really tell a guy who falls for the football trick every time? I just don't want to be like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few late night laptop-clacking screenwriters, bohemians college students inhabit the eclectically decorated and d lit Flight Path Coffee Shop. A twenty-something woman, EL works the counter. She sees HEATH and begins preparing his caramel cappuccino.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Heath, I see you got our mailing about the new dress code. (Louder) None of these other slackers did.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Yeah. Uh, Ellen, this is Doug.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Hello. ELLEN sets HEATH'S drink down.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: And what can I get for you?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Strawberry Smoothie?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: That's a lot of work.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I can get something else.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I'll suck it up. Why don't I bring it out to you. Heath, I believe your table is available. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 91.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Thanks, Ellen. HEATH begins leading DOUG to the appropriate table.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You must come here a lot.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: My rare visits are memorable.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Mmhhhmmm. HEATH leads DOUG to two high-back antique chairs that fac liver shaped vintage coffee table and a puffy couch. Displayed on the wall above this conglomeration is Heath' piece d'art--a 3D cityscape fashioned out of painted boxe various size and shape, toy soldiers, Weebles, model trai Hot Wheels, etc. Everything is cemented down. It hangs li normal, if bulky, painting. HEATH gives DOUG the chair wi the better view of the work.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (noticing the piece) Whoa, funky.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Funky good or funky bad?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (pausing for serious consideration) Funky good. This won't match anyone's couch.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You did this?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Very cool. Is there a theme, some special meaning?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: You mean like man's inhumanity to man or something like that? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 92.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: You know what would be funny?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: If, right here in front of everybody, we took it down off the wall and started playing with it. Moving stuff around, making car sounds.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Wobbling the Weebles.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Are you going to get back together with Troy?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I told him I would.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: He seems all right.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: He is. ELLEN delivers the Strawberry Smoothie.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Here you go.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: So how was prom? If I'm going to have to listen to you go on about it for three weeks, I deserve the scoop.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Boring. The band was lame. Drunks everywhere. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 85 Fortune Cookie - 93.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Ah, too bad. Well the really important thing is you guys look great.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Thanks. ELLEN leaves HEATH and DOUG at their table. DOUG is sombe

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I am so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: It's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETH and TRENT eat ice cream cones as they sit on a bench at a sidewalk table outside of an ice cream shop.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I don't know what the Chinese did before ice cream. If I eat anything spicy, I've gotta have ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You know what they say. You can't miss what you've never had.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Now that sounds like a fortune cookie.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: That must be where I heard it.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I read this thing the other day. It was too long to be a fortune cookie. I think it was a quote from someone semi-famous. It said that a relationship was impossible between two people if their favorite movies couldn't stand to be in the same room together at a party.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Their favorite movies?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Yeah. If movies were personified, would they hit it off? Like, I doubt The Bicycle Thief and Porky's Revenge would be hanging out by the punchbowl together. So what's yours? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 94. 85

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: My favorite movie?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Guess.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Something by Bergman. BETH shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fellini?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Thelma and Louise. BETH doesn't respond. She looks disgruntled. TRENT laughs

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it! That was so easy.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: So what's yours? American Gigolo?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: No, but that's a party I wouldn't want to miss.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: So what is it?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Not important. How is that vanilla? I can't believe you ordered vanilla.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Not so fast, pal. Favorite flick. Let's hear it.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I'm not saying. I'm hoping this way you'll describe me as mysterious to your roommate. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 95. 85

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: After the way I've laid my soul bare to you tonight. So, what does that leave us with? Are we back to first date word games?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I think it may be the only safe territory. You haven't been exactly forthcoming, and every time I've gutted it up and started to tell a story, a real story, you either look like you're going to nod off or you make fun of me.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Really? I don't mean to; it's just that your stories--I don't know--the way they come out; they sound rehearsed. Maybe rehearsed is a bit harsh. It sounds like you're even tired of telling them. I know everyone has stories that they repeat all the time, but...

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: You don't.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I don't. It's too easy. It's like going on dating autopilot. One story to show you're strong. One story to show you're sensitive. One story to show you've got a sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: But isn't that what dating's about. You tell each other your stories. If you like each other's stories, you keep going out.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: There has to be something more to it. I mean, what happens when you run out of stories?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: You live together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG uses a key to open the door of the closed video stor She punches in the alarm code as soon as she enters, but doesn't turn on the lights. Light is provided by streetlights, exit sign, cars, etc. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 96. 86

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: (whispering) Are you sure this is okay?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (normal volume) Sure. I'm just leaving the lights off, so people don't try to come in and rent something. So what do you want to see? HEATH starts walking down the aisles checking out the tit DOUG follows him, not really looking at the videos.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: You know my friend Ryan? The first day he went to work at Dunkin' Donuts, they told him he could eat all the donuts he wanted for free, so, of course, Ryan just pigged out, ate like twenty on his first day.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I can't believe they let him do that.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, they know what they're doing. Ryan ended up getting so sick that he says he'll never eat another donut again. That's their little plan.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Devious.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: So is that how you are with movies? Sick of them?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: They're on when I'm working, so I don't take them home very often. Besides, if there's a movie in the house, it's too easy not to do my homework.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: If there's a toaster in my house, it's easy for me not to do my homework.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Well, I have this secret goal. I got two B's my freshman year, but I haven't made any since.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Same here. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 97. 86

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: The rest have been A's.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: If I get A's the rest of the year, I'll be the salutatorian.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Wow. I always knew you were smart, but there's smart, then there's salutatorian smart. I wouldn't have guessed you were up there. I mean... Don't take that wrong.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: No. I understand. That's the secret part. I don't want anyone to know. I never tell anyone what I made on tests or homework or what I got in a class. I don't even think Troy knows. And it's not that I'm all that smart; my SATs prove that. I just work hard at it.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: That sounds like ambition to me.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Ambition to make good grades seems kind of pointless if there's nothing you really want to do with it, but the scholarship money will come in handy.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: So why don't you want anyone to know.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Because it's so uncool. Not to be smart, really, but to try really hard for something. You say one of the reasons you asked me to the dance was because you didn't think I fit some stereotype, but in a lot of ways, I do. Look at me. I'ma cheerleader who dates a football player and doesn't want anyone to think she's has a brain.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Man, I hope nobody finds out I went out with you.  87 Fortune Cookie - 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drive in parking lot is empty except for CAROLYN'S ca The movie is over. CAROLYN is asleep against Dean's shoul DEAN is awake and staring blankly at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Wake up little Susie. DEAN squeezes CAROLYN with the arm he has wrapped around CAROLYN opens her eyes, yawns...

dialogues.speaker: DEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You missed it. The swamp monster managed to organize all the textile workers into a union.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I was dreaming about the lake house.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: What lake house.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: The one you said I'd be living in when I'm retired.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Was it nice?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: It was too big.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Where to now?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: On our first date, you took me straight home. I thought you must not have liked me very much, you were in such a hurry to get rid of me.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I had forgotten about that.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I wasn't sure you were going to slow down when we got there. I thought I was going to have to do a Charlie's Angels roll out of the car. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 87 88 89 Fortune Cookie - 99.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I remembered halfway through the movie that it was Atilla The Mom's birthday. DEAN and CAROLYN both realize.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: She's on the West Coast, she's probably still awake. CAROLYN starts up the car.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, methodically clipping my face out of every family photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETH and TRENT sit in TRENT'S parked car.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I don't see how you do it. You're not even going to get five hours of sleep.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: The really demented part is that this is what DJs strive for--the morning shift. Prime time in radio land. It's not like, if I get better, they'll give me a shift where I can sleep in. The car is consumed in silence.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Well thanks. I had a nice time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETH pulls at her door handle and starts to get out of th car. TRENT quickly follows suit. The two converse while moving towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I'll walk you up.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I'm fine, really.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: If I don't I won't get my merit badge. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 100.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The rest of the short walk is taken in silence. They arri at the door.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you have a clock alarm?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Set it for seven.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I'll say something to you in code on the air. Everyone will hear it, but you'll be the only one who'll understand.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Oh. I don't think that'll work.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Sure it will.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: My clock alarm--that's all it is. No radio.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: You don't have a radio? BETH shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I've thought about getting one, though. As she says this, TRENT leans in and tries to kiss BETH. head dodges. After appropriate awkwardness...

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (curious, not mean) Have you sent secret coded radio messages to a lot of women? TRENT doesn't respond right away.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You see what I mean? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 89 90 Fortune Cookie - 101.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Women, men, friends, relatives. I guess I ought to be going.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, thanks again.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I had fun.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I'll give you a call. BETH gives a "Yeah, right" nod and opens her door.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Good night, Trent.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Good night. BETH closes the door. TRENT trudges away. He points an imaginary gun at his head and pulls the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETH comes out of her own bedroom having changed into swe bottoms and a T-shirt. She knocks on AMANDA'S door and wa in. AMANDA is still camped in front of her computer

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Hey, what're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Having sex. Can't you tell?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I'll come back later. BETH exits the room. She wanders into the kitchen, opens freezer and contemplates her pint of Ben & Jerry's. Shaki her head in disgust, she pulls it out and gets a spoon. B then sits down on the couch and uses the remote control t turn on Saturday Night Live. She watches a few seconds of some lame skit, but she quickly begins eyeing the CD rack next to the TV. BETH pulls her fortune out of her purse and begins riflin through the CDs. She refers, once again, to the fortune. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 91 92 Fortune Cookie - 102.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ABBA Gold, thirteen... BETH pulls out the ABBA CD. Her finger scans down to the thirteenth track. She takes out the CD and puts it in the deck. "Take A Chance On Me" begins to play. BETH counts t verses out loud.

dialogues.speaker: ABBA
dialogues.text: If you change your mind...

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Line one.

dialogues.speaker: ABBA
dialogues.text: On the mercy line...

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Line two.

dialogues.speaker: ABBA
dialogues.text: Honey I'm still free...

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Three.

dialogues.speaker: ABBA
dialogues.text: Take a chance on me...

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (along with male backing vocalists) Take a chance. Take a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRENT drives home from BETH'S apartment. He's cranks the "Fortune Cookie" that's playing on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEAN is leaning on his Suburban. He's talking to his moth on a cellular phone. CAROLYN is close enough that she can hear what he's saying.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: a lot more money, Mom. ..I know I'd be a lot closer. ..Well, she's got the business to think about. ..And Ann. ..People did a lot of things differently in 1957. Listen, I just wanted to tell you happy birthday. I'll call you tomorrow and fill (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 103.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DEAN (cont'd) you in on the details. Okay? I love you, too. Good night, Mom. DEAN hangs up the phone and tosses it in his vehicle. As two talk they make their way towards the front door...

dialogues.speaker: DEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry. Her opinions are her own and don't reflect those of her offspring.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I'd invite you in, but it looks like Ann's here with her date.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Do you want to come over?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: So this is it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: How soon do they want you out there?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: A month.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: We could still see each other until you have to leave.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: That's no good. I'm one of those people who likes to rip the band aid off, not peel it off slowly. It doesn't hurt as long that way.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I've never broken up with someone that I'm still in love with before. This is one of those times when you know what it feels like to be an adult. By now, they've arrived at the front door.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Anything you need. Ever. Just call.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I need you to do something awful--cheat on me, humiliate me. I can't take this kindness. I need you to break my heart. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 92 93 Fortune Cookie - 104.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I could never do that. DEAN and CAROLYN kiss. Both are near tears.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: You're a good man, Dean Jeffries. CAROLYN kisses DEAN one more time, quickly, and enters th house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG and HEATH sit on the couch, a safe distance between them. They watch The African Queen.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I think that would have been a cool time to be alive.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Yeah, you'd have World War One and the depression to look forward to.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I just liked the idea of wearing a cool hat and getting to say "dames," but since you put it that way. CAROLYN comes in the front door, obviously upset. She wal right past the teenagers on the sofa and enters the kitch DOUG follows her.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Mom? What's wrong? Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I'm okay. I just need something to drink. DOUG pours her mother a glass of water. CAROLYN has taken seat at the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Something happened with Dean?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: We broke up tonight, honey. Dean's moving away.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Moving away? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 105. 93

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: To San Francisco. He got a promotion.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Then what was the ring for? Who gives a ‘breaking up' ring?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: What was what ring for?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: He had a ring. It fell out of his pocket before he picked you up. I saw it. I thought he was going to pop the question tonight. That's why we went to The Empire. I wanted to see your expression when he asked you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: He did.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: He asked you? What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: (realizing) I told him not to be silly.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Mom... CAROLYN stands. She takes the phone down off the wall and begins to dial. Deciding against that plan of action, she hangs it back up. She repeats that process. She picks up purse, then sets it back down again. Terribly confused, s sits.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: All right. What do I say when I get there? Using my X-ray vision, I've noticed a diamond ring in your pocket. Do you mind telling me what you were planning on doing with it?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Tell him not to go.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I can ask him for that. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 106.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I think you better. CAROLYN gets her purse and heads back out of the kitchen, through the living room and out of the front door. DOUG follows her into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shouting after her mom) I won't wait up. CAROLYN pops her head back in the door.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Heath, nice seeing you again. You guys can have another half hour before Heath needs to head home.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: But Mom, that doesn't give us enough time to watch... CAROLYN shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Caligula

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Do you think she was mad because I'm over here and it's after midnight?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Why would she be mad?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: She said she wanted you home early, because you had to work in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, that. She won't care. Hey, you paused the movie.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I didn't want you to miss it..

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Wow. You're the first male of the species I've ever known to pause the movie when somebody else leaves the room. Embarrassed, HEATH finishes his sentence. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 107.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: because then I'd have to tell you what happened when you weren't watching.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I'm glad you asked me out. I've needed to meet someone like you.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I'm glad I did too. I don't think I'd rent the tux if I had it to do all over again, or take dance lessons.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You took dance lessons?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: I figured it was necessary--unless you planned on square dancing. Don't worry. I didn't go out and pay for them. I just had my sister show me. DOUG uses the remote control to turn the TV off. She walk over to a jambox, inserts a cassette and hits play. Some romantic slow song comes on.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Let's see it. Show me what you've learned.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Where's the mirror ball. I don't boogie without a mirror ball. Doug beckons him with her finger.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right. Try to keep up. DOUG places her hands on HEATH'S shoulders. HEATH nervous positions his hands on DOUG'S waist. They begin a type fo dance. After a moment, DOUG scoots in a little closer.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cool. Type three dancing.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Type three?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Better than type four. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fortune Cookie - 108. 93

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Type four...

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Type four--how we dance with lepers.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: (obviously happy) Type three, according to Beth, a girl, is a sure sign of non-revulsion.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You're not going to cut off your ear and mail it to me, are you?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: No, but in my next masterpiece, there might be a weeble-ette in a red dress.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: All right--immortality. They dance for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. I know the answer ..to the riddle ..your fortune. They all get pushed around.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: A lawnmower. A revolving door.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: And a sap.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Oh wow. I wasn't thinking of it that way. What do you think it's supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
